Refined KCC Query [HF]: Fertilizer recommendation for Cashew
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How much fertilizer is required for Cashew plant?
KccAns: kg fym kg urea kg ssp g mop at split
Primary Answer (Level0):
Cashew trees require a balanced fertilizer application to support their vegetative growth and fruit development.
In the first year it is 70:40:60 Kg NPK and in the second year 140:80:120 Kg NPK in the second year. In the third year it progresses to 210:120:180 Kg of NPK for an year and fourth year onwards 280:160:240 kg NPK and from fifth year it is 500:200:300 Kg NPK for a tree. 
These fertilizers should be applied in two equal split doses: one during June–July and the other during October–November. This split application helps in efficient nutrient uptake and supports the tree's growth during critical phases. Fertilizers should be applied in a circular trench around the tree, extending from the base to the drip line, ensuring that the nutrients reach the active root zone.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0):
Cashew trees require a balanced fertilizer application to support their vegetative growth and fruit development.
A total of 60 trees can be planted in an acre with a spacing of 8m x 8m . The nutrient requirement is that42 kg DAP, 81kg urea, and 75 kg MOP per year. In the first year, apply 1/5th of this quantity that is 8 kg DAP, 16 kg urea, 15 kg MOP, in the second year 2/5th, an\d increase proportionally each year to reach the full dose in the 5th year onwards, broadcasting in a 0.5–3 m radius around the tree and incorporating by light raking.

These fertilizers should be applied in two equal split doses: one during June–July and the other during October–November. This split application helps in efficient nutrient uptake and supports the tree's growth during critical phases. Impractical Fertilizer Doses: The answer gives the dose in pure nutrients (N, P, K). An expert answer must translate this into quantities of actual, market-available fertilizers (e.g., Urea, SSP, MOP) in grams per tree.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: Recommendation for Arecanut management
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How much fertilizer is required for Arecanut plant?
Primary Answer (Level0):
fertilizer doses per acre are approximately 40 to 50 kg of nitrogen (N), 12 to 16 kg of phosphorus (P₂O₅), and 12 to 16 kg of potassium (K₂O). 
These nutrients should be applied in split doses, with one-third of the nitrogen and the full dose of phosphorus and potassium applied at the onset of the Kharif season to support early growth. The remaining nitrogen should be applied in two equal splits—one after three months and another after six months. Along with chemical fertilizers, it is beneficial to apply 25 to 30 tons of well-decomposed organic manure such as farmyard manure or compost annually to improve soil health. 
Fertilizers should be evenly spread around the base of the palms, keeping a distance of about one meter from the trunk to avoid root burn, and followed by adequate irrigation to enhance nutrient uptake.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: What is the SRI technique?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the System of Rice Intensification Techniques?
Primary Answer (Level0):
System of Rice Intensification (SRI) is best suited for season with assured irrigation is more suitable. Difficulty in crop establishment may be seen in areas with heavy downpour. The seed rate is 7- 8 kg for single seedling per hill.
A Single  seedling of 15 days old is transplanted per hill following a Square planting of 25 x 25 cm. Later fill up the gaps between 7th and 10th Days After Transplanting. Transplant within 30 minutes of pulling out of seedlings.
Irrigation should be done only to moist the soil in the early period of 10 days and Restoring irrigation to a maximum depth of 2.5cm after development of hairline cracks in the soil until panicle initiation.
Weeding has to be done using rotary weeder or Cono weeder and moving the weeder with forward and backward motion to bury the weeds and as well to aerate the soil at 7-10 days interval from 10-15 days after planting on either direction of the rows and column.

The seed rate is 7-8 kg for a single seedling per hill. A single seedling of 15 days old is transplanted per hill following a square planting of 25 x 25 cm. Later, fill up the gaps between the 7th and 10th days after transplanting. Transplant within 30 minutes of pulling out the seedlings. Irrigation should be done only to moisten the soil in the early period of 10 days and restore irrigation to a maximum depth of 2.5 cm after the development of hairline cracks in the soil until panicle initiation. Weeding has to be done using a rotary weeder or Cono weeder and moving the weeder with forward and backward motion to bury the weeds and also to aerate the soil at 7-10 day intervals from 10-15 days after planting in either direction of the rows and columns.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: Yield of Alphonso Mango
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the estimated yield of Alphonso?
Primary Answer (Level0):
Alphonso mango is a fast growing variety of mango. The seed rate is 60 saplings in an acre under 8m x 8m spacing.
Usually propagated by grafting . 
Alphoso trees start bearing fruits from the 5th year of planting. The yield, however, varies depending on the variety and climatic conditions. The first-year yields are generally low (3-5 Kg per tree), increasing gradually in subsequent years.

Crossandra( Crossandra infundibuliformis L.) is sown during the month of July - October. There are mainly two varieties Crossandra cultivated in Tamil Nadu .Tetraploid types some of them are  Orange, Lutea Yellow, Sebaculis Red.and Triploid types that is  Delhi Crossandra.

The seed rate is 2.5 Kh/ acre and for Delhi Crossandra rooted cuttings is used for planting.

An average yield of 800 kg of flowers per acre/year can be obtained. In Delhi Crossandra, 1120 kg of flowers per ha per year can be obtained.

In Tamil Nadu, two main types are cultivated: tetraploid varieties, such as Orange, Lutea Yellow, and Sebaculis Red, and the triploid variety, Delhi Crossandra. Rooted cuttings of Delhi Crossandra are used for planting. The average yield is about 8 quintals per acre for tetraploid varieties and 11 quintals per acre for the triploid variety.

QueryText: oil extracting method for medicinal plants
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Oil extracting method for medicinal plants
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the process of Oil extracting method in Medicinal plants?
KccAns: asked to contact tnau medicinal plants department -
QueryText_normalized: oil extracting method for medicinal plants
Primary Answer (Level0): In Nagapattinam, farmers can extract oil from medicinal plants like lemongrass, tulsi, and neem using simple methods like hydrodistillation and steam distillation. For example, lemongrass leaves can be boiled in water, and the steam that rises carries the oil, which is then cooled and collected. Similarly, tulsi leaves can be steamed to release their essential oil. Neem oil can be extracted by boiling crushed neem seeds. These methods are low-cost and suitable for village-level use, using basic tools like a pot, fire, and a collecting container. For better yield, advanced machines like microwave or ultrasound extractors can be used, but they are more expensive. Traditional distillation remains the best and easiest option for most farmers.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Nagapattinam, farmers can extract oil from medicinal plants like lemongrass, tulsi, and neem using simple methods like hydrodistillation and steam distillation. For example, lemongrass leaves can be boiled in water, and the steam that rises carries the oil, which is then cooled and collected. Similarly, tulsi leaves can be steamed to release their essential oil. The correct method for neem oil is cold pressing the kernels, which produces pure oil for commercial use. For small-scale farmers, Neem Seed Kernel Extract (NSKE) is a practical solution—crushing the kernels, soaking them in water, and using the liquid as a natural pesticide.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding loans available in cooperative societies
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the loans available in Cooperative society?
Primary Answer (Level0): In Nagapattinam, farmers can access agricultural loans through Primary Agricultural Cooperative Credit Societies (PACS), which are available in most villages. These societies offer short-term crop loans up to ₹1 lakh without any collateral, mainly used for buying seeds, fertilizers, and other cultivation needs. For crops like sugarcane, loans are provided based on land area, often covering up to 10 acres. Medium-term loans are also available for 3 to 5 years, used for buying tractors, irrigation pumps, or livestock. Interest rates are low, and farmers who repay loans on time often get interest subsidies from the government, reducing their overall repayment burden.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Farmers can access agricultural loans through the Kisan Credit Card (KCC) scheme, offered by Primary Agricultural Cooperative Credit Societies (PACS). The collateral-free loan limit under KCC is ₹1.6 lakh, which can be used for purchasing seeds, fertilizers, and other inputs. For sugarcane, loans are based on land area, covering up to 10 acres. Medium-term loans (3-5 years) are also available for purchasing tractors, irrigation pumps, or livestock. Loans come with low interest rates, and farmers who repay on time may receive interest subsidies from the government. The KCC is the main loan product supporting farmers' financial needs for agricultural activities.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: Brinjal yield
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the yield of Brinjal?
Primary Answer (Level0): In Sivaganga, Tamil Nadu, during the Zaid season (March to June), brinjal cultivation gives good yields when managed properly. Local varieties like Co-2, PKM-1, and MDU-1 generally produce around 100 to 120 quintals per acre. On the other hand, hybrid varieties such as Neelam, Annamalai, and Arka Anand perform much better, giving yields of 240 to 320 quintals per acre. These hybrids are more tolerant to heat and pests, making them ideal for summer planting. With proper irrigation, pest control, and regular harvesting every 4–5 days after 55–60 days of planting, farmers can achieve high and consistent yields.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Sivaganga, Tamil Nadu, brinjal cultivation during the Kharif season (June to September) can be highly productive if managed properly. The Kharif season, characterized by heavy rainfall, requires selecting brinjal varieties that are rain-tolerant and capable of withstanding waterlogging and fluctuating weather conditions. For Kharif brinjal cultivation, high-yielding, rain-tolerant varieties should be prioritized. Local varieties such as Co-2, PKM-1, and MDU-1 are reliable, yielding around 100 to 120 quintals per acre. However, hybrid varieties like Neelam, Annamalai, and Arka Anand perform significantly better in the Kharif season. These hybrids are more pest-resistant and better suited to the rainy conditions, with potential yields ranging from 240 to 320 quintals per acre. To achieve high yields, farmers should ensure proper irrigation (especially in the early stages), implement effective pest control, and conduct regular harvesting every 4–5 days, starting around 55–60 days after planting. By following these practices, farmers can achieve consistent and high yields throughout the Kharif season.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critically Incorrect Season: The biggest and most significant error. The question is for the KHARIF season. The provided answer gives a detailed yield analysis for the Zaid (summer) season. This is a fundamental mistake that makes the entire answer irrelevant to the user's query.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Fruit borer?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Fruit borer?
KccAns: Apply endosulfan EC mllit or malathion EC mllit
Primary Answer (Level0): During the Zaid season in Sivaganga, crops like brinjal, okra, and chillies  are often attacked by fruit borers. These pests bore into young fruits, leaving visible holes with black frass and causing the fruits to rot or fall prematurely. To control fruit borers, farmers should remove and destroy infested fruits regularly. Pheromone traps (4–5 per acre) help monitor and trap adult moths. For organic control, spray Neem oil 3% @ 600 ml/acre or NSKE 5% @ 5 kg/acre, every 10–12 days. In case of heavy infestation, chemical sprays like Emamectin benzoate 5 SG @ 80 g/acre, Flubendiamide 480 SC @ 60 ml/acre, or Chlorantraniliprole 18.5 SC @ 60 ml/acre can be used. Sprays should be done in the evening and repeated every 10–12 days, while maintaining a 5-day pre-harvest interval for food safety. Regular monitoring and a mix of these methods help keep fruit borers under control across crops.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): During the Kharif season in Sivaganga, crops like brinjal, okra, and chillies are prone to attacks by fruit borers, which bore into young fruits, causing visible holes filled with black frass and leading to premature fruit rot or fall. Sprays should be applied in the evening to minimize harm to beneficial insects and repeated every 10–12 days while adhering to the specific PHI to ensure food safety. Regular monitoring, along with a mix of these methods, helps farmers keep fruit borers under control and protect their crops during the Kharif season.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Leaf spot disease?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Leaf spot?
Primary Answer (Level0): In Sivaganga, during the Zaid season, crops like brinjal, tomato, and chillies often suffer from leaf spot disease, which appears as brown or black circular spots on the leaves. These spots can merge and cause the leaves to yellow and fall off, reducing plant strength and yield. To manage this disease, farmers should remove infected leaves, avoid overcrowding, and maintain good field hygiene. For effective control, spray Mancozeb 75% WP @ 2 kg per acre or Copper Oxychloride 50% WP @ 2.5 kg per acre in 200 litres of water, at intervals of 10–12 days. In severe cases, Tebuconazole 25.9% EC @ 400 ml per acre can be used. Always observe a Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) of 7 days for Mancozeb and Copper Oxychloride, and 3 days for Tebuconazole to ensure safe harvest. Following these steps helps protect crops from leaf spot while keeping the produce safe for consumption.

To manage this disease, farmers should remove infected leaves, avoid overcrowding, and maintain good field hygiene. For effective control, spray Mancozeb 75% WP @ 600-800g per acre or Copper Oxychloride 50% WP @ 800g - 1kg per acre in 200 litres of water, at intervals of 10–12 days. Always observe a Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) of 7 days for Mancozeb and Copper Oxychloride, and 3 days for Tebuconazole to ensure a safe harvest. Following these steps helps protect crops from leaf spot while keeping the produce safe for consumption.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: What are medicinal plants?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the medicinal plants?
Primary Answer (Level0): 16 medicinal plant species traditionally used by rural communities to treat poisonous bites—including those from snakes, scorpions, insects, and rats. Among these, Musa paradisiaca (plantain) was most commonly cited, while preparations generally involved using leaves (43.8%), mostly as oral extracts or decoctions (62.5%), and taken as drinks (64.7%). In another survey near the Vettangudi Water Bird Sanctuary (Sivagangai district), several locally common herbs were noted: Trianthema portulacastrum (Saaranathi): a root decoction used to relieve stomach pain. Vinca rosea (Nithiyakalyaani): leaf extract brewed with milk and consumed twice daily to treat fevers. Vitex negundo (Notchi): burned leaves are used for cold and cough relief by inhaling the vapour. These findings highlight both the diversity of medicinal flora in Sivaganga and their practical uses in local healthcare.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Sivaganga, the favorable climate and fertile soil offer great potential for cultivating medicinal plants like Musa paradisiaca (plantain), Trianthema portulacastrum (Saaranathi), Vinca rosea (Nithiyakalyaani), and Vitex negundo (Notchi). Plantain is propagated using suckers and requires spacing of 1.8–2.4 meters, yielding around 25–30 tons per hectare. Saaranathi, which is used for stomach pain relief, grows well in well-drained soils and produces 1–1.5 tons of dried roots per hectare. Nithiyakalyaani and Notchi are grown for their medicinal leaves, which yield 1.5–2 tons of dried leaves per hectare. These plants benefit from organic fertilizers and pest control, such as neem oil. With a growing demand for medicinal herbs in the local and global markets, prices for these plants range from ₹500 to ₹15,000 per kilogram, depending on the species. By combining traditional knowledge with modern agricultural practices, farmers in Sivaganga can turn medicinal plant cultivation into a sustainable and profitable business.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Fails to Provide Cultivation Details: The biggest flaw is that it is a descriptive summary, not a cultivation guide. A farmer asking for "medicinal detail" needs to know how to grow these plants. The answer provides zero information on propagation methods, spacing, fertilizer requirements, pest/disease management, or harvesting.

Missing All Quantification: The advice is not useful for a commercial grower as it provides no yield potential (e.g., kg of dried leaves per acre) or information on the market demand and price for these specific herbs. Without this data, a farmer cannot make an informed decision to cultivate them.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Bud rot in Coconut?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Bud rot in coconut?
KccAns: Spray bordeaux mixture after remon val of affeted region
Primary Answer (Level0): In Tiruvannamalai, bud rot in coconut is a serious disease, especially during the rainy or humid Zaid season. Symptoms include yellowing and wilting of young leaves, rotting of the central bud (spear) with a foul smell, leading to the death of the palm crown. The disease thrives in humid, waterlogged conditions and dense plantations. To manage it, ensure good drainage and proper spacing. Apply 1% Bordeaux mixture at the rate of 300 ml per palm as a preventive spray before monsoon and repeat every two months. . For dwarf varieties, place 2 g mancozeb sachets in leaf axils to protect during rains. In nurseries and young palms, apply biocontrols like Trichoderma asperellum at 25 g per soil application and spray Bacillus subtilis at 10 g per liter of water.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Tiruvannamalai, bud rot in coconut palms is most severe during the Kharif (monsoon) season. Symptoms include yellowing leaves, rotting of the central bud, and a foul smell, leading to the death of the palm crown. The disease thrives in humid, waterlogged conditions. To manage bud rot, first clean the crown by removing infected tissue, then apply 1% Bordeaux mixture (100 g copper sulfate + 100 g lime in 10 liters of water) at 300 ml per palm before the monsoon and repeat every two months. For dwarf varieties, place 2 g mancozeb sachets in the leaf axils during rains. For young palms, apply Trichoderma asperellum (25 g per soil application) and spray Bacillus subtilis (10 g per liter of water) for fungal control. By combining these methods, farmers can effectively manage bud rot and protect their palms during the Kharif season.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incorrect Season: The answer fails to correct the user's premise. Bud rot is most severe during the Kharif (monsoon) season, not the hot, dry Zaid season. Providing advice for the wrong season is a fundamental error.

Impractical Dosage: The Bordeaux mixture recommendation of "300 ml per palm" is a good start, but it's an incomplete instruction. The answer must also provide the standard 1% recipe to prepare the mixture.

Missing Key Control Method: It completely omits the most important step for an infected palm: cleaning the crown by removing all infected tissue before drenching with a fungicide.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: Foliar spray for Casuarina
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the foliar spray for Casuarina?
Primary Answer (Level0): During the Kharif season in Tiruvannamalai, Casuarina trees benefit from regular foliar sprays to boost growth and nutrient uptake. A micronutrient mixture containing zinc, iron, manganese, and boron can be sprayed at a concentration of 3–5 ml per liter, using about 50 to 100 ml of the mixture diluted per plant depending on tree size. Calcium nitrate with magnesium (Calsan-MG) is recommended at 5–6 ml per liter, applying around 75 to 100 ml per plant to promote healthy shoot growth and reduce leaf drop. For boron enrichment, sprays like Borosan should be applied at 3–4 ml per liter, using about 50 to 75 ml per plant to strengthen cell walls and improve resilience. Additionally, bio-stimulants such as Tag Exotica, made from marine extracts, can be applied at 0.5–1 ml per liter, with 10 to 20 ml per plant to help the trees tolerate stress and encourage vigorous growth. It’s best to apply these sprays early in the morning or late evening every 15–30 days, avoiding rainy weather to ensure good absorption and effectiveness.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): During the Kharif season in Tiruvannamalai, Casuarina trees benefit from foliar sprays to boost growth and improve nutrient uptake. A micronutrient mixture containing zinc, iron, manganese, and boron should be applied at 200–250 ml per acre to enhance nutrient availability and tree health. To promote healthy shoot growth and reduce leaf drop, apply Calcium nitrate with magnesium (Calsan-MG) at 300–400 ml per acre. For boron enrichment, a boron-based liquid spray at 100–150 ml per acre helps strengthen cell walls and improve resilience. Additionally, marine extract-based bio-stimulants (e.g., Tag Exotica) can be applied at 100–150 ml per acre to improve stress tolerance and encourage vigorous growth. Apply these sprays early in the morning or late evening every 15–30 days, avoiding rainy weather for optimal absorption.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critically Impractical Dosages: The biggest flaw is recommending doses in "ml per litre" and "ml per plant." This is not a standard or practical method for a large-scale forestry crop.

Missing Correct Information: An expert answer must provide the standard per-acre product dose for these foliar sprays. For example, a standard micronutrient mixture is typically applied at 200-250 ml per acre.

Vague Recommendations: It lists trade names. The advice should be based on the generic nutrient names (e.g., "a multi-micronutrient liquid fertilizer containing Zinc, Iron...").

Refined KCC Query [HF]: Valarum Velanmai book details
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I subscribe to the Uzhavarin Valarum Velanmai magazine from TNAU?
Primary Answer (Level0): Uzhavarin Valarum Velanmai is a Tamil monthly magazine published by the Directorate of Extension Education, Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU), Coimbatore, since 1975. The publication aims to disseminate agricultural technologies and information to farmers and stakeholders across Tamil Nadu. Uzhavarin Valarum Velanmai magazine is made available to farmers through key agricultural institutions like the District Agricultural Office (DAO) and the Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK), Kilnarsapuur. These centers are part of the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University’s (TNAU) outreach programs and regularly distribute the magazine to promote modern and region-specific farming practices. The magazine covers useful topics such as crop planning, pest management, organic farming, and government schemes. Farmers can either collect monthly issues directly from these offices or request a subscription.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Uzhavarin Valarum Velanmai is a Tamil monthly magazine published by the Directorate of Extension Education at Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU), Coimbatore, since 1975. The publication aims to provide farmers across Tamil Nadu with practical agricultural knowledge, covering important topics such as crop planning, pest management, organic farming, and updates on government schemes. The magazine is distributed through key agricultural institutions like the District Agricultural Office (DAO) and the Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK) located at the TNAU Agricultural Research Station in Vrinjipuram, Tiruvannamalai, which are part of TNAU’s outreach efforts. Farmers can access the magazine by collecting it directly from these centers or can subscribe by sending a demand draft to the TNAU Directorate of Extension Education. The annual subscription fee is typically ₹100, though farmers should confirm the exact amount with the local office or TNAU’s website.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critically Incorrect KVK Location: The biggest error is naming the KVK as "Kilnarsapuur." This is incorrect. The official and primary Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK) for Tiruvannamalai district is located at the TNAU Agricultural Research Station in Vrinjipuram. This is a major factual error that misdirects the farmer.

Incomplete Subscription Info: A complete guide would also provide the practical steps for subscribing, including the annual subscription fee and the procedure for sending a demand draft to the TNAU Directorate of Extension Education.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to contact machinery department?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to contact machinery department?
Primary Answer (Level0): The Agricultural Engineering Department in Tiruvannamalai plays a key role in supporting farmers with modern machinery and equipment. Headed by the Assistant Executive Engineer, the department offers services such as machinery maintenance camps, equipment demonstrations, subsidies, and access to the e-rental scheme. Recently, a machinery maintenance camp was held in Isanya Maidan, showcasing tractors, harvesters, and mobile repair units. Over the past four years, the department has distributed equipment worth over ₹21 crore, including sugarcane harvesters, electric motors, and solar-powered pumps, benefiting more than 1,600 farmers. Farmers can also rent machinery at subsidized rates through the e-rental scheme, making advanced tools accessible even to smallholders. For enquiries, farmers can contact the Agricultural Engineering Office at Venkikal Village, Tiruvannamalai, or email (aedeetvm@tn.nic.in).
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): The Agricultural Engineering Department in Tiruvannamalai plays a crucial role in supporting farmers with modern machinery and equipment. Headed by the Assistant Executive Engineer, the department offers services such as machinery maintenance camps, equipment demonstrations, subsidies, and access to the e-rental scheme. A recent machinery maintenance camp in Isanya Maidan showcased tractors, harvesters, and mobile repair units. Over the past four years, the department has distributed more than ₹21 crore worth of equipment, including sugarcane harvesters, electric motors, and solar-powered pumps, benefiting over 1,600 farmers. Refined KCC Query [HF]: Fertilizer dose for CO43 variety at 30th day
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How much fertilizer is required for CO43 Variety on the 30th day of crop?
KccAns: APPLY KG UREAKG POTASH KG NEEM CAKEACRE
Primary Answer (Level0): CO 43 is a salt-tolerant and submergence-tolerant rice variety developed in Tamil Nadu, India. It is known for its fine quality, suitable for both raw and boiled rice. It matures in 135-140 days and is a semi-dwarf type. CO 43 is also used as a parent variety in breeding programs to develop other rice varieties, including those with enhanced submergence tolerance. At 30 days after sowing (DAS), CO 43 rice reaches the active tillering stage, which is critical for crop development. At this stage, apply 30 kg/ha of Nitrogen and 10 kg/ha of Potassium (K₂O) as a second split dose. These nutrients support tiller formation and healthy growth. Phosphorus should already be given as a full basal dose at planting. If zinc deficiency symptoms appear (like yellowing of leaves), apply a 0.5% Zinc Sulphate foliar spray. Timely application at this stage ensures better yield potential and stronger plants.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): CO 43 is a salt- and submergence-tolerant rice variety developed in Tamil Nadu, recognized for its fine quality and suitability for both raw and boiled rice. It matures in 135-140 days and is used in breeding programs for varieties with enhanced submergence tolerance. At 30 days after sowing (DAS), when the rice reaches the active tillering stage, it’s crucial to apply 26 kg of Urea per acre (providing 12 kg of Nitrogen) and 20 kg of Muriate of Potash (MOP) per acre (providing 10 kg of Potassium (K₂O)). Phosphorus should already have been applied as a basal dose during planting. If zinc deficiency symptoms such as yellowing leaves are noticed, a 0.5% Zinc Sulphate foliar spray should be applied. This nutrient schedule is specifically recommended for the Kharif season, as CO 43 is not typically cultivated during the Jayad season in Tamil Nadu.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critically Incorrect and Impractical Fertilizer Dose: The biggest error is that the fertilizer dose is given in pure nutrients per hectare (e.g., "30 kg/ha of Nitrogen"). This is a scientific, not a practical, recommendation.

Missing Correct, Actionable Information: An expert answer must translate this into quantities of actual, market-available fertilizers in per-acre units. For example, 30 kg/ha of Nitrogen is approximately 12 kg/acre, which is supplied by about 26 kg of Urea per acre. This is the most crucial piece of information, and it is completely missing.

Fails to Address the "JAYAD" Query: The answer provides a correct schedule for a Kharif crop but fails to first correct the user's premise about the Jayad season, as paddy is not grown then.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding Mullai varieties CO 1 and CO 2
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the Mullai varieties - CO1 and CO2?
Primary Answer (Level0):
No, the Mullai varieties CO 1 and CO 2 are not typically cultivated during the Zaid season. Zaid crops are summer crops planted between March and June, whereas Mullai (Jasmine) is generally planted between June and November. Well-drained red loamy soil is suitable for jasmine cultivation. Regular watering is needed, with weekly irrigation being sufficient under normal weather conditions. CO 1 variety is a secondary clonal selection, yielding an average of 41 quintal /acre per year.
The flower buds are pink-tinged with a long corolla tube. It is suitable for oil extraction. CO 2 variety is an induced mutant developed from CO 1, known for its bolder buds compared to CO 1. CO 2 yields an average of 50 quintals of flower buds per acre. It is amenable for quicker and earlier tying of buds for garland making.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Mullai varieties CO 1 and CO 2 are not cultivated during the Zaid season but are typically planted during the monsoon season, from June to August. CO 1 is a secondary clonal selection, yielding 41 quintals per acre, and is used primarily for oil extraction due to its pink-tinged buds. CO 2, developed from CO 1, produces 50 quintals per acre and has bolder buds, making it ideal for garland making. A crucial practice in jasmine cultivation is pruning, typically done in the last week of November to regulate plant growth and promote a concentrated flowering season. Regular weekly irrigation is sufficient under normal conditions to support healthy growth.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Vague Planting Time: The planting window of "June to November" is too broad. An expert answer must be more specific. The main commercial planting time for Jasmine in Tamil Nadu is during the monsoon season, from June to August.

Missing Most Important Cultural Practice: The biggest flaw is the complete omission of pruning. Pruning is the single most important operation in Jasmine cultivation to regulate growth and ensure a profitable, concentrated flowering season. An expert must provide the correct pruning time, which is typically the last week of November.

QueryText: ENQUERY ABOUT NUSERY FERITILIZER MANGEMENT in Paddy
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Nursery fertilizer management in Paddy
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended fertilizer dose for a paddy nursery for transplanting?
Primary Answer (Level0): For a paddy nursery in Tamil Nadu during the Kharif season, a common fertilizer recommendation per acre is to apply 1 tonne of well-rotted FYM or compost per acre and mix it thoroughly into the soil by ploughing twice, followed by irrigation. This helps improve soil structure and nutrient availability. Apply 26 kg of urea per acre at the time of puddling. Apply 60 kg of superphosphate per acre at the time of puddling.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): For a paddy nursery in Tamil Nadu during the Kharif season, the fertilizer application for a 20-cent nursery (which is sufficient to transplant one acre of paddy) should include 8.5 kg of DAP (Diammonium Phosphate). This should be applied during the preparation of the nursery bed to provide essential phosphorus for strong root development and nitrogen for initial seedling growth. 17 kg of Urea should be applied at the time of puddling, which helps to supply the required nitrogen for healthy seedling growth and early-stage vigor. These applications are in line with TNAU's recommended practices for efficient nursery management and optimal seedling development, ensuring that the nursery can support healthy plants for transplanting into the main field, covering one acre.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Catastrophic Dosage Error: The most significant and dangerous flaw is that it recommends fertilizer doses (26 kg Urea, 60 kg Superphosphate) on a "per acre" basis for a nursery. A one-acre nursery is a massive area that would be used to transplant 50-100 acres of the main field. This is a fundamental misunderstanding of scale.

Missing Correct Information: A farmer raises a very small nursery (typically 20 cents or 1/5th of an acre) to transplant one acre of the main field. The fertilizer recommendation must be for this small nursery area, not for a full acre. The standard TNAU recommendation is to apply about 8.5 kg of DAP and 17 kg of Urea for the 20-cent nursery area required for one acre of transplanting.

These applications are in line with TNAU's recommended practices for efficient nursery management and optimal seedling development, ensuring that the nursery can support healthy plants for transplanting into the main field, covering one acre.
Comment (Reviewer2): Urea Should be applied at 10 DAS instead of puddling.

And 17 kg of urea should be applied 10 days after sowing, which helps to supply the required nitrogen for healthy seedling growth and early-stage vigor. Final Answer: For a paddy nursery during the Kharif season, the fertilizer application for a 20-cent nursery (which is sufficient to transplant one acre of paddy) should include 40 kg of DAP (Diammonium Phosphate). This should be applied during the preparation of the nursery bed to provide essential phosphorus for strong root development and nitrogen for initial seedling growth. And 17 kg of urea should be applied 10 days after sowing, which helps to supply the required nitrogen for healthy seedling growth and early-stage vigor. These applications are in line with TNAU's recommended practices for efficient nursery management and optimal seedling development, ensuring that the nursery can support healthy plants for transplanting into the main field, covering one acre.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Ergot disease in Cumbu (Pearl millet)?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Ergot diseases in Pearl millet?
Primary Answer (Level0): Ergot disease is a significant problem in Cumbu (pearl millet) crops, especially in Tamil Nadu. The symptoms of ergot are most visible during and after the flowering stage of the Cumbu crop. The first symptom is the appearance of sticky, sugary liquid droplets (honeydew) on the infected earheads. Later, hard, dark-brown to black, horn-like structures called sclerotia replace the normal grains. To control ergot disease, Soak seeds in a 2% salt solution (20g salt per liter of water) to remove infected seeds. Wash with fresh water and dry before sowing. Avoid planting Cumbu in the same field year after year. A foliar spray is the recommended method for application with chemicals like Carbendazim (50% WP) @ 200 grams per acre or Propiconazole (25% EC) @ 200 ml per acre with around 80-160 litre water per acre.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Ergot disease is a major issue in Cumbu (pearl millet) crops, particularly in Tamil Nadu. Symptoms typically appear during and after the flowering stage, with sticky honeydew forming on the infected earheads, followed by the growth of dark, horn-like sclerotia that replace the normal grains. To manage ergot, soak seeds in a 2% salt solution (20g salt per liter of water) to remove infected seeds, then wash and dry them thoroughly before sowing. Avoid monocropping by practicing crop rotation to reduce disease buildup. For foliar treatment, instead of Carbendazim, use a modern, safer fungicide like Tebuconazole 50% + Trifloxystrobin 25% WG at a dose of 80-100 grams per acre. Apply the fungicide at the 50% flowering stage for effective protection against infection. It’s crucial to follow the Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) specified on the product label to ensure the safety of the food crop and to avoid harmful residues.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Recommends an Outdated/Risky Chemical: The biggest flaw is the recommendation of Carbendazim. This fungicide is being phased out and is under review for a complete ban in India due to health and environmental concerns. An expert must always recommend safer, modern alternatives.

Missing Safe Alternatives: A responsible expert answer would replace Carbendazim with a more modern and effective systemic fungicide like Tebuconazole 50% + Trifloxystrobin 25% WG at a dose of 80-100 grams per acre.

Missing Strategic Timing: The advice for spraying is vague. An expert must specify that the spray is most effective when applied at the 50% flowering stage to protect the florets from infection.

Critical Safety Omission: The advice is unsafe because it completely omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) or waiting period after spraying, which is a non-negotiable safety rule for a food crop.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: From where can I get Tree killer?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: From where can I get Tree killer?
Primary Answer (Level0): Tree killer is an unique product of Tamil Nadu Agricultural University produced through a revolving fund scheme at the Department of Plant Pathology, Centre for Plant Protection Studies.  The chemical is sold at Agricultural Technology Information Centre of the Directorate of Extension Education, Coimbatore. Since the tree killer has an ingredient which is highly toxic, it needs to be handled with great care. It should not come into direct contact with human body. It should be kept out reach of children. The container after use has to be buried and disposed off safely. The tree killer totally eradicates trees and shrubs that cause nuisance at temple premises, roof tops, walls of buildings, wells, canal bunds and shutters. The bark around the base of tree / shrub to be killed has to be removed to a height of 10 cm from the ground. The tree killer has to be swabbed using a brush over the area of the stem without bark immediately before it dries. Further a waste cloth has to be tied / wound around the area which is to be soaked / drenched with the chemical again. It is enough if tree killer is applied once. Trees will start drying after some time and they will not revive.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Tree Killer is a chemical developed by Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU) to control unwanted trees and shrubs in places like temple premises, rooftops, and canal bunds. It is effective but highly toxic and available only at TNAU, Coimbatore—making it impractical for most farmers. A more accessible and recommended method is the cut-stump technique, where the tree is cut near the base and a concentrated solution of Glyphosate 41% SL (mixed 1:1 with water) or 2,4-D Sodium Salt is applied immediately to the fresh cut. These systemic herbicides kill the roots and prevent regrowth. They are safe when used correctly, affordable, and easily available in local pesticide shops—making them a more practical choice for farmers across Tamil Nadu.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Provides an Impractical Solution: The biggest flaw is that the advice is limited to a specialty product available from a single location (TNAU, Coimbatore). This is not a practical solution for a farmer in a different district who cannot travel there to purchase it.

Missing the Generic and Widely Available Alternative: An expert answer must provide the standard, generic method that can be used with commonly available chemicals. The advice is incomplete as it fails to mention this.

Missing Correct Information: A complete and practical answer would explain that the same "cut-stump" method can be performed using a common, systemic herbicide that is available in any local pesticide shop. The expert recommendation should be to cut the tree and then immediately paint the freshly cut stump with a concentrated solution of Glyphosate 41% SL (often mixed 1:1 with water) or 2,4-D Sodium Salt. This is the standard, effective, and most accessible method for any farmer in Tamil Nadu.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: From where can I get Durian?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: From where can I get Durian?
Primary Answer (Level0): If you want to plant Durian (Durky) in Tamil Nadu, the safest place to get seedlings is from TNAU-approved nurseries and Government Horticulture Farms. The most trusted spot is the State Horticulture Farm at Burliar in Nilgiris, just on the Ooty–Coimbatore highway, where farmers are already getting good and healthy saplings. Apart from Burliar, other state horticulture farms across Tamil Nadu also supply certified durian and tropical fruit plants. Always remember buy only certified planting material, because that alone gives true-to-type trees, better growth, and disease-free yield. If you go for uncertified saplings, later you may face poor yield and pest issues. For contacts, Burliar farm number is 04233-224995, and you can also reach out to TNAU Horticultural College, Coimbatore or your local KVK for guidance and training. Along with planting, follow TNAU package like proper manuring, irrigation, and for disease issues, which keeps fungal attack under control. So, best way is—get certified saplings from government farms, follow TNAU advice, and in few years you will get good income from this high-value fruit.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding Kaadai (quail)
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to rear Kaadai (quail)?
KccAns: CONTACT THE ASSOCIATE PROFESSER AND HEAD VETERINARY UNI TRAINING RESEARCH CENTRE THIRUPUR - -
Primary Answer (Level0): If you want to rear Kaadai (Japanese Quail) in Tamil Nadu, it is really a good choice because these small birds grow fast, give quick income, and need very little space. Farmers here mostly go for Japanese quail variety (Coturnix japonica) which lays around 250 eggs per year and gives good meat yield also. You can rear them any time in the year, but best results and market price usually come in post-monsoon season (October to March). For housing, you can keep them in deep litter system with 1 sq ft per bird or in multi-tier cages to save space. For breeding, keep one male with 3–4 females. Small farmers can easily start with 200–500 chicks per batch, and within 4–6 weeks the birds reach market weight of about 200–250 grams. Egg laying starts by 6 weeks, with eggs weighing 9–13 grams, and if you manage well, livability is around 95%. Always buy chicks only from TANUVAS Veterinary College, Namakkal, or government-approved centers, because local uncertified chicks often give poor yield. For management, keep house clean and dry (cultural control), use probiotics in feed for strong immunity (biological control), and if any disease comes, use approved medicines but only with vet’s advice. Keep temperature around 25–30°C and humidity 50–70% for best growth. Give balanced feed with maize, soymeal, and other protein supplements, plus always provide clean water. If you follow these steps, you will get good eggs and meat yield, less mortality, and steady income from Kaadai farming.

QueryText: asking about incubation period of duck
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Incubation period of Duck
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the incubation period of Duck?
QueryText_normalized: asking about incubation period of duck
Primary Answer (Level0): For ducks the incubation period is 28 days, and this is same for common breeds like Khaki Campbell which many farmers in Tamil Nadu rear. You can either let a broody duck sit and hatch naturally, or you can use an artificial incubator if you want more control and higher hatch rate. In incubators, keep the temperature around 37.2–37.5°C (99–99.5°F) and maintain proper humidity. For the first 25 days, keep wet-bulb temperature near 30–31°C (86–88°F), then slightly increase to 33°C (90°F) in the last 3 days. Always turn eggs every hour and from day 2 to 25 sprinkle a little lukewarm water mixed with sanitizer to keep shells moist and clean. On day 7, do candling to check if embryos are growing, and by day 25 shift eggs to the hatcher. After hatching, ducklings need brooding for 3–4 weeks, starting with around 32°C (90°F) temperature and then slowly reducing. Keep clean water of 2–3 inch depth so they can drink and play but not drown, and give balanced starter feed. For health, keep incubator and brooding area always dry and clean (cultural control), use probiotics in water to build immunity (biological control), and if any infection comes, consult vet and use medicines only as vet guidance. If you follow these simple steps, you will get good hatch rate, healthy ducklings, and more profit from duck farming in Tamil Nadu.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): For ducks the incubation period is 28 days, and this is same for common breeds like Khaki Campbell which many farmers in Tamil Nadu rear. The Muscovy duck has a much longer incubation period of 35 to 37 days. You can either let a broody duck sit and hatch naturally, or you can use an artificial incubator if you want more control and higher hatch rate. If you follow these simple steps, you will get good hatch rate, healthy ducklings, and more profit from duck farming in Tamil Nadu.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critical Omission (Species Variation): The answer gives a single incubation period for all ducks, which is a major error. It is critical to differentiate:

The 28-day period is correct for common ducks (like Khaki Campbell).

The Muscovy duck has a much longer incubation period of 35 to 37 days.

For health, keep incubator and brooding area always dry and clean (cultural control), use probiotics in water to build immunity (biological control), and if any infection comes, consult vet and use medicines only as vet guidance. If you follow these simple steps, you will get good hatch rate, healthy ducklings, and more profit from duck farming in Tamil Nadu.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: What is meant by incubator?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is meant by incubator? how it is used in Animal husbandry?
Primary Answer (Level0):
An incubator is a specially designed device that provides the right temperature, humidity, and ventilation to hatch eggs artificially without a broody hen. It helps hatch eggs of chickens, ducks, quails, and other birds efficiently and on a large scale. So chicks can grow and come out healthy. Farmers in Tamil Nadu use incubators for chicken, duck, kaadai (quail), and even turkey eggs when they want to hatch many eggs at one time. Using incubator is good because you control everything – heat steady around 37.5°C for chicken, 37.2°C for duck, water moisture kept 50–60%, and eggs turned many times daily. In small models, you turn eggs by hand; in big automatic models, machine itself turns eggs and keeps right moisture. Because of this, hatch percentage becomes high, and chicks come out uniform and strong. It is available in two types:
Small manual incubator – cheap, good for backyard farmers, but you must turn eggs daily.
Big automatic incubator – costly, but easy for commercial farmers, everything automatic, less labour. Before putting eggs, always wash and clean the incubator with safe disinfectant. During hatching, sprinkle little clean water if needed to keep moisture, and always check temperature. After 7 days, do candling with a torch to see if embryo growing. In Tamil Nadu, incubators are available in Coimbatore, Chennai, Namakkal side shops and also through government supply chain. If you ask your local KVK or TNAU extension office, they will guide to reliable dealers. With incubator you no need to wait for broody hen mood, you can hatch eggs any time of year and in bulk also. That means steady chicks, steady income.

Comment (Reviewer1):
Critically Incomplete Information: The humidity recommendation is incomplete and will lead to poor hatch rates. It is critical to specify the two different humidity phases:

Setter (First 18 days for chicken): Humidity should be 50-60%.

Hatcher (Final 3 days): Humidity must be increased to 65-75% to ensure a successful hatch.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to rear chicken?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the process of Rearing chicks?
Primary Answer (Level0): Chicken rearing in Tamil Nadu is a simple and sure income work if we follow right steps, broilers like Cobb 500, Vencobb and Ross 308 grow fast and reach near 2 kg weight in just 6–7 weeks, while layers like White Leghorn and Rhode Island Red lay around 250–280 eggs in a year, so first make clean shed with good airflow and dry litter using rice husk or sawdust, keep chicks warm at 32–35°C in starting and slowly reduce to 24°C when they grow, always give clean drinking water and proper feed with 22–24% protein for broilers and 16–18% for layers, keep shed neat, separate sick birds, disinfect well, and use probiotics for good digestion, medicines should be given only with doctor advice and remember withdrawal time before sale, vaccination against New Castle and Marek’s disease must be done in time, feed cost is big so save by giving right feed at right time, and if you use poultry droppings in farm do soil and water testing to avoid damage, always buy chicks from government hatcheries or TNAU recommended suppliers, if you do all these simple things, birds will be healthy, grow well and surely give you good money.

Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Chicken rearing can provide reliable income if proper steps are followed. Broilers like Cobb 500, Vencobb, and Ross 308 grow fast and reach around 2 kg in 6–7 weeks, while layers like White Leghorn and Rhode Island Red lay approximately 250–280 eggs per year. First, prepare a clean shed with good airflow and dry litter using rice husk or sawdust. Keep chicks warm at 32–35 °C initially and gradually reduce to 24 °C as they grow. Always provide clean drinking water and proper feed: 22–24% protein for broilers and 16–18% for layers. Layers also need 14–16 hours of light daily to maintain egg laying. Maintain shed hygiene, separate sick birds, disinfect regularly, and use probiotics to support digestion. Medicines should be given only on veterinary advice, observing withdrawal periods before sale. Vaccinate birds against Newcastle disease and Marek’s disease on schedule. Feed is a major cost, so optimize feeding by giving the right feed at the right time. If using poultry droppings as fertilizer, conduct soil and water tests to avoid damage. Always buy chicks from government hatcheries or TNAU-recommended suppliers. Following these steps ensures healthy birds, good growth, and profitable returns.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to rear dove birds?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to rear a Dove bird?
Primary Answer (Level0): Dove rearing in Tamil Nadu is a simple and low-cost work that any small farmer can do, these birds like Indian Ring Neck Dove and Spotted Dove grow well in our climate and they need only small space, a clean shed or cage with good air and protection from cats and kites is enough, they eat our local grains like millet, sorghum, cracked wheat and rice bran, just keep clean water always, for breeding one male with three females is good and give them soft nest material like straw or dry grass, they lay eggs fast and hatch quickly so income comes early, doves are strong birds but still we must keep house clean, remove waste, disinfect cages and give probiotics in feed for good health, if birds fall sick directly connect with vet and always use medicine only with veterinary advice and remember withdrawal time before sale, vaccination and health check from local animal husbandry office is good, cost is very less compared to chicken or duck and still meat and ornamental value bring good price in market, farmers can buy good chicks from government hatchery or TNAU recommended breeder, if we keep hygiene, feed proper grains and follow vet advice, dove rearing surely gives safe income with very less risk for our Tamil Nadu farmers.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Dove rearing in Tamil Nadu is a simple and low-cost work that any small farmer can do, these birds like Barbary Dove (Streptopelia risoria grow well in our climate and they need only small space, a clean shed or cage with good air and protection from cats and kites is enough, they eat our local grains like millet, sorghum, cracked wheat and rice bran, just keep clean water always, for breeding one male with three females is good and give them soft nest material like straw or dry grass, they lay eggs fast and hatch quickly so income comes early, doves are strong birds but still we must keep house clean, remove waste, disinfect cages and give probiotics in feed for good health, if birds fall sick directly connect with vet and always use medicine only with veterinary advice and remember withdrawal time before sale, vaccination and health check from local animal husbandry office is good, cost is very less compared to chicken or duck and still meat and ornamental value bring good price in market, farmers can buy good chicks from government hatchery or TNAU recommended breeder, if we keep hygiene, feed proper grains and follow vet advice, dove rearing surely gives safe income with very less risk for our Tamil Nadu farmers.
Comment (Reviewer1): Critical Legal & Biological Error: The recommendation to rear the Indian Ring Neck Dove and Spotted Dove is a major error. These are wild, protected species under the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972, and it is illegal to capture or keep them. The commonly farmed species is the domesticated Barbary Dove (Streptopelia risoria).

Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to use chick incubator?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the use of Chick Incubator?
Primary Answer (Level0): Chick incubator is a simple machine that helps us hatch eggs without hen, it keeps steady heat around 37.5°C and humidity near 50–60% so chicks grow inside egg properly, the machine also turns eggs often so embryo will not stick and air can move in and out for breathing, with this you can hatch many eggs together and get more healthy chicks compared to natural brooding, you can use TNAU recommended incubators get better hatch rate, less loss and quick supply for market, before and after use always clean and disinfect incubator, check heat and humidity setting, candle eggs and remove bad ones, incubators are available in Coimbatore, Chennai and other towns from poultry suppliers, and training or guidance you can take from KVK or TNAU centers, so bhai if we keep incubator neat, follow setting properly and use good eggs, you can hatch plenty of chicks at one time and earn good profit easily.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Chick incubator is a simple machine that helps us hatch eggs without hen, it keeps steady heat around 37.5°C and humidity near 50–60%  for the first 18 days (setter), then increased to 65-75% for the final 3 days (hatcher). so chicks grow inside egg properly, the machine also turns eggs often so embryo will not stick and air can move in and out for breathing, with this you can hatch many eggs together and get more healthy chicks compared to natural brooding, you can use TNAU recommended incubators get better hatch rate, less loss and quick supply for market, before and after use always clean and disinfect incubator, check heat and humidity setting, candle eggs and remove bad ones, incubators are available in Coimbatore, Chennai and other towns from poultry suppliers, and training or guidance you can take from KVK or TNAU centers, so bhai if we keep incubator neat, follow setting properly and use good eggs, you can hatch plenty of chicks at one time and earn good profit easily.
Comment (Reviewer1): Critically Incomplete Information: The humidity recommendation is incomplete and will cause poor hatching. It is critical to specify the two phases: humidity should be 50-60% for the first 18 days (setter), then increased to 65-75% for the final 3 days (hatcher).

Updated with Reviewer4 (Level 4): A chick incubator is a simple machine that helps hatch eggs without a hen. It maintains a steady temperature of around 37.5 °C and humidity near 50–60% for the first 18 days (setter), then increases humidity to 65–75% for the final 3 days (hatcher). This ensures that embryos develop properly. The machine also turns the eggs regularly so the embryo does not stick to the shell and air can circulate for proper breathing. Using an incubator allows you to hatch many eggs at once and produce healthier chicks compared to natural brooding. Using TNAU-recommended incubators gives better hatch rates, reduces losses, and ensures a quicker supply of chicks for the market. Before and after use, always clean and disinfect the incubator, check the temperature and humidity settings, candle the eggs to remove unfertile or bad ones, and maintain hygiene. Incubators are available in Coimbatore, Chennai, and other towns from poultry suppliers. For training or guidance, you can contact local KVKs or TNAU centers. By keeping the incubator clean, following the correct settings, and using good-quality eggs, you can hatch a large number of chicks at one time and earn good profit.

It maintains a steady temperature of around 37.5 °C and humidity near 50–60% for the first 18 days (setter), then increases humidity to 65–75% for the final 3 days (hatcher). This ensures that embryos develop properly. The machine also turns the eggs regularly so the embryo does not stick to the shell and air can circulate for proper breathing. Using an incubator allows you to hatch many eggs at once and produce healthier chicks compared to natural brooding. Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to rear turkey birds?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the process of Rearing Turkey?
Primary Answer (Level0): Turkey rearing is slowly becoming popular in Tamil Nadu because meat demand is good and birds give nice returns, the common types you can rear here are Broad Breasted Bronze and Broad Breasted White which are available from government hatcheries, for housing we can keep them in deep litter system giving one square feet space per poult at start and later 1.5 sq.ft by 8 weeks, for small chicks we must keep heat around 32–35°C and slowly reduce after brooding, feed should be rich with 22–24% protein for fast growth, one male can manage 3–4 females, eggs weight about 70 g each and hatching takes 28 days, birds start laying at 24–28 weeks and give 80–100 eggs in a year, for meat purpose market age is 16 weeks where male reaches 3.5 kg and female 2.5 kg, normally they need 3.5 kg feed to gain 1 kg body weight and mortality in first 8 weeks is around 3–4%, for health we must keep house clean, litter dry, give probiotics in feed and only use medicines under doctor or vet advice, in our Tamil Nadu condition free range or semi-intensive method is best for small farmers because feed cost reduces when you use local grains and greens, always give clean water and air flow for less disease, in early days give vitamins and protein supplements for better survival, poults should be bought only from TNAU hatcheries or Animal Husbandry approved farms and reputared authorized farms, and for any training or technical support you can contact with nearest KVK or TNAU centers, if you follow these simple steps bhai, turkeys grow healthy, survive well and surely give good profit for you.

Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Turkey rearing is slowly becoming popular due to good demand for meat and attractive returns. The common types reared here are Broad Breasted Bronze and Broad Breasted White, which are available from government hatcheries. For housing, poults can be kept in a deep litter system, with one square foot per bird initially and 4–5 sq. ft per bird by 8 weeks. During brooding, maintain temperature at 32–35°C for small chicks and gradually reduce it as they grow. Feed should be protein-rich (22–24%) for fast growth. One male can manage 3–4 females. Eggs weigh about 70 g each, and the incubation period is 28 days. Birds start laying at 24–28 weeks, producing 80–100 eggs per year. For meat, turkeys reach market age at 16 weeks, with males weighing around 3.5 kg and females 2.5 kg. Typically, 3.5 kg of feed is needed to gain 1 kg body weight, and mortality in the first 8 weeks is around 3–4%. For health management, keep the house clean, litter dry, provide probiotics in feed, and use medicines only under veterinary guidance. In Tamil Nadu, free-range or semi-intensive systems are ideal for small farmers, as feed costs are reduced by using local grains and greens. Always provide clean water and good airflow to reduce disease, and give vitamins and protein supplements in early days to improve survival. Poults should be purchased only from TNAU hatcheries or authorized Animal Husbandry farms. For training or technical support, farmers can contact their nearest KVK or TNAU centers. Following these practices ensures healthy turkeys, better survival, and good profit.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Emu mouth disease?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Emu mouth disease?
Primary Answer (Level0): Emu mouth disease is a problem we see where birds start drooling and get small wounds inside mouth and throat, because of that they cannot eat properly, they become weak and if not treated some may even die, first signs we notice are too much saliva, ulcers inside mouth, difficulty in swallowing and less movement, to control this we must keep emu shed clean, dry and airy, separate sick birds quickly and wash feeders and drinkers daily to prevent spread quickly, giving probiotics in feed will help birds stay strong and to boost emu immunity and gut health, if infection is serious doctor may give Oxytetracycline 10 mg per kg body weight or Enrofloxacin 5 mg per kg, always use only under vet advice and follow withdrawal time before selling meat, also give soft feed, clean water and vitamins to help birds recover, early treatment saves life and reduces loss,if we watch birds daily, keep shed neat and call vet in time, emus will stay healthy and give good growth and profit for you.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Emu mouth disease is a fungal infection Candidiasis (Thrush) problem we see where birds start drooling and get small wounds inside mouth and throat, because of that they cannot eat properly, they become weak and if not treated some may even die, first signs we notice are too much saliva, ulcers inside mouth, difficulty in swallowing and less movement, to control this we must keep emu shed clean, dry and airy, separate sick birds quickly and wash feeders and drinkers daily to prevent spread quickly, giving probiotics in feed will help birds stay strong and to boost emu immunity and gut health, if infection is serious immidiately contact with nearest vetinery, and only under vet advice use  antifungal medication and follow withdrawal time before selling meat, also give soft feed, clean water and vitamins to help birds recover, early treatment saves life and reduces loss,if we watch birds daily, keep shed neat and call vet in time, emus will stay healthy and give good growth and profit for you.
Comment (Reviewer1): Incorrect Diagnosis & Treatment: "Emu mouth disease" is not a specific disease. The symptoms described are classic signs of the fungal infection Candidiasis (Thrush). Recommending antibiotics (Oxytetracycline, Enrofloxacin) is a critical error, as they are ineffective against fungi and can worsen the condition. The correct treatment requires antifungal medication from a veterinarian.

Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2):
Emu mouth disease is a fungal infection called Candidiasis (Thrush). Birds affected by this disease start drooling and develop small wounds inside the mouth and throat. Because of this, they cannot eat properly, become weak, and if not treated, some may even die. The first signs include excessive saliva, ulcers inside the mouth, difficulty swallowing, and reduced movement.

To control the disease, keep the emu shed clean, dry, and well-ventilated. Separate sick birds quickly and wash feeders and drinkers daily to prevent rapid spread. Adding probiotics to the feed helps boost immunity and maintain gut health. If the infection is severe, immediately contact a veterinarian, and only under their guidance use antifungal medications, following withdrawal periods before selling meat. Provide soft feed, clean water, and vitamins to help recovery.

By watching the birds daily, maintaining a neat shed, and calling the vet on time, emus can stay healthy, grow well, and provide good profit.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control chicken viral disease?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control chicken viral disease?
Primary Answer (Level0): In our poultry farming the most dangerous trouble comes from viral diseases and if you don’t follow TNAU advice properly whole flock can go down in few days , among these the Ranikhet disease or Newcastle disease is most feared because it spreads very fast through saliva, droppings or water and once it enters shed chicks start sneezing, gasping, drooping, some show green loose motion, some twist neck and finally many die suddenly, in unvaccinated flock even 100% death can happen, farmers lose birds, eggs, and income all at once, then you may face vet bills, disinfectant cost, government checks and even market bans. Next Infectious Bronchitis which looks like cold and cough in chickens but very harmful as birds stop growing, lay poor quality or misshapen eggs and may your egg sales fall. Then Marek’s disease attacks mainly young chicks causing paralysis in legs and wings and even tumors inside body, birds waste away and immunity also drops, farmer has to replace flock and spend more money. Also next one is Infectious Bursal Disease which farmers call Gumboro, it kills young chicks by white diarrhea, swollen bursa and weakens their immunity, mortality can touch 80–90% and even surviving birds never grow well, farmers may face major profit loss and disease recurrence costs. Last one is Avian Influenza or Bird Flu is very severe, suddenly birds die with bleeding, swelling in face and comb, whole farm can be sealed and culled by government, no sale allowed and farmer goes into heavy loss both money wise and heart wise. So, main point is these viral diseases bring big losses—dead birds, poor growth, low eggs, extra medicine cost, market ban, and even neighbor farms get affected, only way to save is to vaccinate strictly on TNAU schedule and as per vetinery advice. So first thing when doubt comes you should not wait, you must call or reach the Poultry Disease Diagnosis and Surveillance Lab (PDDSL) at Namakkal (phone 04286-266226, mail: adl-vcri@tanuvas.org.in, as number may change best to reach official website https://www.tanuvas.ac.in/lab_pddl.php for uptodate details. Even TANUVAS technology centre at Madhavaram Milk Colony, Chennai is there to support. Keep sheds neat, don’t allow visitors inside, wash hands and feet before entering, give good probiotics, vitamins and immunity boosters to strengthen birds, vaccination is the main weapon because no antibiotic can kill virus, so schedule must be followed strictly, for example Marek’s at 0 day, Ranikhet Lasota at 5–7 days, IB vaccine at 10th day, IBD live at 12–14 days, then booster as per calendar, only if secondary bacterial problem comes vet may give Oxytetracycline or Enrofloxacin, but never use medicines blindly, always under vet advice, vaccines and support are available at Veterinary College Namakkal, Poultry Research Station Chennai, TANUVAS hospitals and nearest KVKs across districts. By following this steps you can save your brid from this viral disease.

So first thing when doubt comes you should not wait, you must call or reach the Poultry Disease Diagnosis and Surveillance Lab (PDDSL) at Namakkal (phone 04286-266226, mail: adl-vcri@tanuvas.org.in, as number may change best to reach official website https://www.tanuvas.ac.in/lab_pddl.php for uptodate details. Even TANUVAS technology centre at Madhavaram Milk Colony, Chennai is there to support. Keep sheds neat, don’t allow visitors inside, wash hands and feet before entering, give good probiotics, vitamins and immunity boosters to strengthen birds, vaccination is the main weapon because no antibiotic can kill virus, so schedule must be followed strictly, for example Marek’s at 0 day, Ranikhet Lasota at 5–7 days, IB vaccine at 10th day, IBD live at 12–14 days, then booster as per calendar, only if secondary bacterial problem comes vet may give Oxytetracycline or Enrofloxacin, but never use medicines blindly, always under vet advice, vaccines and support are available at Veterinary College Namakkal, Poultry Research Station Chennai, TANUVAS hospitals and nearest KVKs across districts. By following this steps you can save your brid from this viral disease.

Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): In poultry farming, the most dangerous trouble comes from viral diseases, and if TNAU advice is not followed properly, the whole flock can be lost in a few days. Among these, Ranikhet disease or Newcastle disease is the most feared because it spreads very fast through saliva, droppings, or water, and once it enters the shed, chicks start sneezing, gasping, drooping; some show green loose motion, some twist their necks, and finally many die suddenly. In unvaccinated flocks, even 100% mortality can occur, causing farmers to lose birds, eggs, and income at once, and then face veterinary bills, disinfectant costs, government checks, and even market bans. Next, Infectious Bronchitis, which looks like a cold and cough in chickens, is very harmful as birds stop growing, lay poor-quality or misshapen eggs, and egg sales may fall. Marek’s disease attacks mainly young chicks, causing paralysis in legs and wings and even tumors inside the body; birds waste away, immunity drops, and farmers have to replace the flock and spend more money. Infectious Bursal Disease, or Gumboro, kills young chicks by causing white diarrhea, swollen bursa, and weak immunity; mortality can reach 80–90%, and even surviving birds never grow well, resulting in major profit loss and recurring disease costs. Avian Influenza, or Bird Flu, is extremely severe, with sudden deaths, bleeding, swelling in the face and comb; the whole farm can be sealed and culled by the government, and no sale is allowed, causing heavy financial and emotional loss. These viral diseases bring big losses—dead birds, poor growth, low eggs, extra medicine cost, and market restrictions—and neighboring farms may also be affected. The only way to prevent them is strict vaccination following the TNAU schedule and veterinary advice. Farmers should not wait when doubts arise; they must contact the Poultry Disease Diagnosis and Surveillance Laboratory (PDDSL) at Namakkal (phone 04286-266226, mail: adl-vcri@tanuvas.org.in, or check https://www.tanuvas.ac.in/lab_pddl.php for updated contact) or the TANUVAS Technology Centre at Madhavaram Milk Colony, Chennai. Sheds must be kept neat, visitors restricted, hands and feet washed before entry, and birds should receive probiotics, vitamins, and immunity boosters. Vaccination is the main defense since antibiotics cannot kill viruses. For example, Marek’s disease is vaccinated at 0 day, Ranikhet Lasota at 5–7 days, Infectious Bronchitis vaccine at 10th day, and IBD live vaccine at 12–14 days, followed by boosters as per the schedule. Secondary bacterial problems, if any, may be treated under veterinary supervision with antibiotics like Oxytetracycline or Enrofloxacin. Vaccines and support are available at Veterinary College Namakkal, Poultry Research Station Chennai, TANUVAS hospitals, and local KVKs. By following these steps, farmers can protect their flocks from viral diseases, ensure healthy growth, prevent mortality, and secure steady income.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: What is Ranikhet fever in chicks and how to manage it?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is Ranikhet fever in chicks and how to manage it?
KccAns: contact to saravanampatti animal husbandary centre--
Primary Answer (Level0): Ranikhet disease which we also call Newcastle disease is a dangerous viral infection that spreads very fast in chicks, chickens, turkeys and ducks, if birds are not vaccinated it can even kill whole flock, main signs you can see they are sneezing, coughing, gasping for breath, birds sitting dull with less feed intake, sometimes twisting of neck or even paralysis, layers stop laying suddenly, watery droppings and swelling near eyes and neck also come, to prevent this you must keep shed always clean, dry and airy, separate sick birds quickly, control visitors and wash equipment with disinfectant, giving probiotics in feed and vitamins during stress will make birds stronger and to boost gut heath and improve immunity. most important protection is vaccine, first dose of Lasota vaccine should be given in drinking water or spray at 4–7 days, booster again at 4–6 weeks and one more dose at 16–18 weeks for layers and breeders, adults can also be protected with inactivated vaccine by injection, if any secondary bacterial infection comes then doctor may prescribe Oxytetracycline 10 mg per kg or Enrofloxacin 5 mg per kg body weight, medicines must be used only with vet advice early vaccination and strict hygiene save our flock and money, so always buy chicks from TNAU approved hatcheries, follow vaccine schedule and take help from Animal Husbandry officers and also can conect with nearest KVK for safe and profitable poultry farming.

As a critically important and restricted antibiotic, it should not be mentioned in a general guide to avoid promoting its misuse and contributing to antibiotic resistance.

Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Ranikhet disease, also called Newcastle disease, is a dangerous viral infection that spreads very fast in chicks, chickens, turkeys, and ducks. If birds are not vaccinated, it can even kill the entire flock. Main signs include sneezing, coughing, gasping for breath, dullness, reduced feed intake, twisting of the neck or paralysis, sudden drop in egg production in layers, watery droppings, and swelling near the eyes and neck. To prevent the disease, always keep the shed clean, dry, and airy; separate sick birds quickly; control visitors; and disinfect equipment. Giving probiotics in feed and vitamins during stress helps strengthen birds, improve gut health, and boost immunity. The most important protection is vaccination: the first dose of Lasota vaccine should be given in drinking water or by spray at 4–7 days, a booster at 4–6 weeks, and a third dose at 16–18 weeks for layers and breeders. Adult birds can be protected with inactivated vaccine by injection. If secondary bacterial infections occur, a veterinarian may prescribe Oxytetracycline (10 mg/kg) or Enrofloxacin (5 mg/kg body weight). Medicines must always be used under veterinary guidance. Early vaccination and strict hygiene protect the flock and save money. Always buy chicks from TNAU-approved hatcheries, follow the vaccination schedule, and seek guidance from Animal Husbandry officers or the nearest KVK to ensure safe and profitable poultry farming.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: Where are turkey chicks or poults available?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Where are turkey chicks or poults available?
Primary Answer (Level0): Turkey chicks which we call poults are now easily available in Tamil Nadu and many farmers are taking them because market demand is increasing, mostly varieties like Broad Breasted White and Broad Breasted Bronze are reared here, you must buy from trusted hatcheries or TNAU recommended suppliers otherwise we may end up with weak or disease-prone birds. Also you can collect from reputated farm like in Kattuputhur there is Krishna Turkey Chick Production running since 1994 giving good quality poults, in Coimbatore Yamunai Natukozhi Farm also supplies turkey chicks along with country chicken, in Salem Hindusthan Poultry Farm provides day-old poults and even farmer support, generally rate goes around ₹100 to ₹300 per chick depending on breed and numbers. Once poults come home keep shed clean, dry and airy, give balanced feed and fresh water, follow vaccination schedule properly as per TNAU or vet department, antibiotics like Oxytetracycline 10 mg per kg body weight should be used only if doctor prescribes, best practice is to check with local KVK or TNAU extension center for verified contacts and training. If you rear with care from start, turkey farming will give you good survival, fast growth and steady income, so always buy right, neat rear, and earn well.

Always buy poults from trusted sources such as government university hatcheries like TANUVAS, State Animal Husbandry Department farms, or TNAU-recommended suppliers to ensure disease-free, true-to-breed birds. After bringing poults home, keep the shed clean, dry, and airy; provide balanced feed and fresh water; and follow the vaccination schedule as per TNAU or veterinary advice. If poults are reared carefully from the start, turkey farming can result in good survival, fast growth, and steady income, making it a profitable venture.

Always buy poults from trusted sources, such as government university hatcheries like TANUVAS, State Animal Husbandry Department farms, or TNAU-recommended suppliers, to ensure disease-free, true-to-breed birds. Reputable private farms, such as Krishna Turkey Chick Production in Kattuputhur (operating since 1994), Yamunai Natukozhi Farm in Coimbatore, and Hindusthan Poultry Farm in Salem, also supply high-quality day-old poults with farmer support. Prices generally range from ₹100 to ₹300 per chick, depending on breed and quantity. After bringing poults home, keep the shed clean, dry, and well-ventilated; provide balanced feed and fresh water; and follow the vaccination schedule as per TNAU or veterinary advice. Antibiotics, such as Oxytetracycline (10 mg/kg body weight), should be used only under veterinary prescription. For verified contacts and guidance, consult the local KVK or TNAU extension center. If poults are reared carefully from the start, turkey farming can result in good survival, fast growth, and steady income, making it a profitable venture.
